DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump tweeted that the US has been losing USD 600bln-800bln on trade and loses USD 500bln with China which he suggested will not happen anymore. (Twitter)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer confirmed the US will increase tariffs on China on Friday if there is no deal and that China was reneging on commitments. Lighthizer also commented we have seen an erosion of commitments from China over the last week and that there has been no contact with China Vice Premier Liu He over the last 24 hours. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US-China trade deal was 90% done and that talks saw a big change in direction. Mnuchin added that there were communications over the weekend that moved the agreement substantially backwards and that the US were in the process of planning a Trump-Xi summit, while he also suggested the US would reconsider the duties if talks get back on track. (Newswires)

China delegation will still travel to the US for trade talks despite US President Trump's threats, according to sources. (CNBC)

PBoC stated RRR cuts are to be implemented for some small & medium sized banks in 3 phases on 15th May, 17th June and 15th July. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May was reportedly warned that MPs will move to oust her as soon as this week if she agrees to a Brexit deal with Labour involving a customs union. (Telegraph)

  • EU Retail Sales (Mar) Y/Y 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 2.8%, Rev. 3.0%). (Newswires)
  • EU Markit Services PMI (Apr F) 52.8 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.5) 
  • EU Markit Composite PMI (Apr F) 51.5 vs. Exp. 51.3 (Prev. 51.3) 

 

FX

BoC Governor Poloz said that Chinese moves against Canadian canola and pork exports are downside risks to the Canadian economy and cannot say now if this risk will become long-term. (Newswires)

Turkey's High Election Board ruled to re-run the Istanbul local elections on the grounds that some of the ballot box officials were not actually civil servants with the rerun to be held on 23rd June. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US continues to see Iranian activity that suggests an escalation, while reports noted that Israel passed intelligence to the White House about a potential Iranian plot to attack US interests in the Gulf. (Newswires/Axios)

 

US

Fed reportedly sees trade tensions as the preeminent short-term risk although it sees financial risks little changed since last fall as the sector appears resilient, while it added that risk appetite remains elevated and overall leverage remains low. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (Non-Voter, Dove) sees one rate hike this year and one next year at most, while he added that more data is needed to convince him that weak inflation requires monetary policy adjustments. Furthermore, Harker commented that we do not have a lot of policy space to deal with a recession right now and that we are currently close to neutral rates, while he suggested a 'wait and see' approach on policy amid uncertainty on how trade tensions will be resolved. (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Nearly every stock in the Nasdaq 100 opened in the red after the return of ‘Tariff Man’ put the prospect of a US/China deal (which would have increased the certainty surrounding their international supply chains) in doubt. Apple (AAPL) opened lower, with the stock price also weighed down by news that the iPhone maker is to be investigated buy the European Commission on an antitrust basis after Spotify (SPOT) issued a formal complaint. Facebook (FB) and Twitter (TWTR) also opened in negative territory after US President Trump took a swipe at the social media platforms for their de-platforming of controversial right-wing activists. IBM (IBM) stock prices could not reverse pre-market losses despite news emerging that the technology co. expects to complete the acquisition of Red Hat by the end of the year. Tesla (TSLA) reversed early losses, despite news emerging that the electric car maker will not have its China-manufactured computer for the Model 3 removed from the basket of goods that may be subject to US President Trump’s upcoming 25% tariff. Lyft (LYFT) shares came under pressure pre-market, as it emerged that drivers working for ride hailing technology companies are planning to strike this week over pay and working conditions. It was not just the technology sector that felt the burn as the threat of tariffs re-emerged. Industrials suffered such as 3M (MMM), Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA) all suffered. Boeing (BA) was also weighed down by a plethora of negative headlines; another 737 MAX plane crashed over the weekend (this time, thankfully, non-lethally) and damning stories emerged that the aircraft maker had been taking shortcuts regarding the safety of its 737 MAX aircraft. Disney (DIS) managed to reverse early losses, after the entertainment co. finalised the sale of 21 of its regional sports networks and ticket sales for ‘Avengers: Endgame’ broke more records over the weekend. Pfizer (PFE) managed to reverse early trade tension related losses after the pharma co. announced approval from the FDA for some of its new headline drugs. One of few stocks to make significant gains on the day, Anadarko (APC) accepted an improved offer from Occidental (OXY), the offer which carries a 23% premium over Chevron’s (CVX) original offer. Chevron (CVX) and Occidental (OXY) shares both moved higher on the news. SPX -0.4% at 2933, NDX -0.7% at 7794, DJI -0.3% at 26437.

After the US President threw his trade toys out of the pram over the weekend, volumes and therefore moves were lacklustre as fixed income traders saw little reward to trading the now binary possibilities of a US/Sino deal/no deal (in addition to multiple market holidays). As such treasuries saw little volatility as the President’s huffing and puffing gave a tailwind to fixed income futures, which steadily climbed throughout the session in thin ranges. Harker also failed to add impetus after largely reiterating Fed guidance, stating that inflation dampening effects are likely transitory, and saw 10yrs close with gains of around 9 ticks and the curve moderately steeper. As such traders are likely looking ahead to a trading week set to be chock-full of trade talk deliberations and upcoming USD 84bln worth of supply this week kicked off by USD 38bln in 3yrs tomorrow. US T-note futures (M9) settled 9 ticks higher at 123-20+

US MARKET WRAP 6 MAY 2019: Stocks rebound off lows, Chinese delegation will come to US despite Trump threats
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities down, Dollar flat, Treasuries up, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Trade talks steel the limelight, Chinese delegation to travel to US despite Trump threats, stocks pare losses on thin volumes, Turkey to re-run local elections in Istanbul

* COMING UP: AU Retail Sales, RBA Rate Decision, GE Industrial Orders, EC Economic Forecast, US Jolts Jobs Openings, CA Ivey PMI, API Weekly Crude Stocks, EIA Short Term Energy Outlook, BoE’s Cuncliffe & Haldane, Fed’s Kaplan & Quarles, Riksbank’s Ingves

* TUESDAY’S EARNINGS: Allergan, Emerson Electrical, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Primoris Services, AB Inbev, BMW, CNH Industrial, Infineon, Intesa Sanpaolo, Henkel, Hannover RE, Pandora, Ferrari, Siemens Gamesa

* US/CHINA TRADE: US-China trade has become the main theme of today, and very likely for the rest of the week (at least), with weekend tweets from US President Trump who ramped up tensions with China by stating that the current 10% tariffs on USD 200bln worth of Chinese goods will be hiked to 25% on Friday. Furthermore, the US President also noted that the currently untaxed USD 325bln worth of goods will be subject to 25% tariffs, although the exact timeframe of this is unknown. Reportedly, Trump’s twitter threats came amid USTR Lighthizer telling the US President last week that Beijing were backtracking on the deal. China’s response has not, as of yet, included any threats to hike tariffs on their side, although there were reports that the country was mulling cancelling trade discussions with the US, scheduled for this week. Moreover, Reports from SCMP noted that Vice Premier Liu He could delay his trip to Washington by three days and shorten discussions to just one day. Markets reacted to the news as expected, stock markets plummeted with China the marked underperformer as Shanghai Comp slid in excess of 5% whilst Shenzhen plummeted 7.5%. The follow-through to the European and US markets were also material but to a much lesser extent. FX markets were also impacted with most majors losing ground vs. the Greenback and USD/CNH gapping higher at 6.8200 (vs. Friday’s close of sub-6.7400) at the open, whilst T-note futures opened higher by 12 ticks and WTI futures fell 2%. Since then, sources stated that a small Chinese delegation will be heading to Washington for dialogue despite Trump’s threats, although it is still unclear whether Vice Premier Liu He will be part of that delegations. Analysts at ING still expect a deal to happen as they note that the tweets are more of a negotiating strategy, albeit a risky one. Meanwhile, Danske Bank note that the implications of a trade war on the stock markets will pressure the two sides to find some sort of common ground in terms of a deal.

* TURKEY: The ongoing election saga had a blowout breakthrough in Monday’s session after an AK party representative stated that elections are to be re-run in the no-longer-AKP-ruled Istanbul. After multiple sessions of consternation with the calamitous results for the incumbent Government, a rationale for a re-run was reached, and cited crony polling counters as the reason. With the re-run now officially confirmed, Turkey watchers will now look forward to the slated June 23rd reset date, with Erdogan’s Government finally given some minor respite.

* WTI (M9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.31 HIGHER AT USD 62.25/BBL; BRENT (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.39 HIGHER AT USD 71.24/BBL. The energy market has nursed the downside seen at the electronic trade open as the soured tone from trade tensions somewhat waned amid looming supply woes emanating from Iranian and Venezuelan sanctions alongside the ongoing OPEC-led production cuts ahead of the JMMC meeting this month. The energy complex edged higher in the US session following a report via Axios which noted that Israel has passed intelligence to the White House about a potential Iranian plot to attack US interests in the Gulf. US Acting Defence Secretary highlighted the US will hold Iran accountable for any attack on US forces or interests, whilst Secretary of State Pompeo noted that the US continues to see Iranian activity that suggests an escalation. Due to the possible ramifications of the latest developments, with scope for tighter Iranian sanctions, oil is poised to end the session in the green and above USD 71.50/BBL for Brent and WTI above USD 62.50/BBL. Analysts at BAML agree that the rally in energy prices have been supply driven, with OPEC+ production contracting by 2.2mln BPD since the OPEC pact in November 2018. The analysts envisage Brent remaining above USD 70/BBL as Iranian oil exits the market, although they expect Saudi to slowly replace the missing barrels.

* SPX -0.4% at 2933, NDX -0.7% at 7794, DJI -0.3% at 26437. SECTORS: Communications -0.8%, Cons Discretionary -0.6%, Cons Staples -0.2%, Energy -0.1%, Financials -0.7%, Healthcare +0.6%, Industrials -1%, Materials -1.4%, Tech -0.8%, Telecoms -0.2%, Utilities -0.6%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Nearly every stock in the Nasdaq 100 opened in the red after the return of ‘Tariff Man’ put the prospect of a US/China deal (which would have increased the certainty surrounding their international supply chains) in doubt. Apple (AAPL) opened lower, with the stock price also weighed down by news that the iPhone maker is to be investigated buy the European Commission on an antitrust basis after Spotify (SPOT) issued a formal complaint. Facebook (FB) and Twitter (TWTR) also opened in negative territory after US President Trump took a swipe at the social media platforms for their de-platforming of controversial right-wing activists. IBM (IBM) stock prices could not reverse pre-market losses despite news emerging that the technology co. expects to complete the acquisition of Red Hat by the end of the year. Tesla (TSLA) reversed early losses, despite news emerging that the electric car maker will not have its China-manufactured computer for the Model 3 removed from the basket of goods that may be subject to US President Trump’s upcoming 25% tariff. Lyft (LYFT) shares came under pressure pre-market, as it emerged that drivers working for ride hailing technology companies are planning to strike this week over pay and working conditions. It was not just the technology sector that felt the burn as the threat of tariffs re-emerged. Industrials suffered such as 3M (MMM), Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA) all suffered. Boeing (BA) was also weighed down by a plethora of negative headlines; another 737 MAX plane crashed over the weekend (this time, thankfully, non-lethally) and damning stories emerged that the aircraft maker had been taking shortcuts regarding the safety of its 737 MAX aircraft. Disney (DIS) managed to reverse early losses, after the entertainment co. finalised the sale of 21 of its regional sports networks and ticket sales for ‘Avengers: Endgame’ broke more records over the weekend. Pfizer (PFE) managed to reverse early trade tension related losses after the pharma co. announced approval from the FDA for some of its new headline drugs. One of few stocks to make significant gains on the day, Anadarko (APC) accepted an improved offer from Occidental (OXY), the offer which carries a 23% premium over Chevron’s (CVX) original offer. Chevron (CVX) and Occidental (OXY) shares both moved higher on the news.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 9 TICKS HIGHER AT 123-20+. After the US President threw his trade toys out of the pram over the weekend, volumes and therefore moves were lacklustre as fixed income traders saw little reward to trading the now binary possibilities of a US/Sino deal/no deal (in addition to multiple market holidays). As such treasuries saw little volatility as the President’s huffing and puffing gave a tailwind to fixed income futures, which steadily climbed throughout the session in thin ranges. Harker also failed to add impetus after largely reiterating Fed guidance, stating that inflation dampening effects are likely transitory, and saw 10yrs close with gains of around 9 ticks and the curve moderately steeper. As such traders are likely looking ahead to a trading week set to be chock-full of trade talk deliberations and  upcoming USD 84bln worth of supply this week kicked off by USD 38bln in 3yrs tomorrow.

* FX WRAP: USD was relatively rangebound as it continued to recover off its post NFP lows, seeing slight upside as US traders arrived at their desks to digest the weekend’s events but ultimately finishing the session relatively flat. JPY was the main G10 beneficiary amid the risk off start to the week, in which USDJPY gapped back below the 111.00 handle and nearly hit 110.00. The Yen did later weaken, as the risk sentiment somewhat improved whilst European and US stocks came off their lows. EUR held up well vs the majority of its G10 counterparts, with the notably exception of the Yen, the eurozone currency supported by promising Markit Comp/Services PMI data this morning. GBP weakened throughout the day, following comments from senior Labour figures, who threw cold water over the prospect of an imminent cross-party breakthrough. AUD/NZD, having both been hit after the re-emergence US tariff threats, could not recover the weekend’s losses vs USD, with the prospect of rate cuts later this week in both economies undermining any recovery. The Aussie ultimately consolidated just below the psychologically important 0.7000 handle. Conversely, the Scandi crowns, NOK and SEK, did manage to recover most of the weekend’s losses as oil prices staged a recovery, stronger than expected PMI data from their European neighbours lifted spirits and market expectations for the Norges Bank to maintain a hiking bias in their meeting later this week remained firmly intact. On the EM front, TRY took a beating as news emerged that Turkish AK Party representatives to the high election board ruled in favour of re-running of local elections in Istanbul, USDTRY convincingly breaking the 6.0000 level for the first time since last November. CNH, which had weakened substantially in the aftermath of the Trump tweets, continued to recoup losses vs USD throughout the session, a recovery assisted by news that a Chinese delegation would travel to the US for negotiations despite.

subject: Chinese delegation will still come to the US for trade talks despite US President Trump's threats, as according to sources cited by CNBC
content: Source
reaction_details:
• E-Mini S&P went from 2930 to 2935 and NASDAQ went from 7780 to 7810
  • Price action has been relatively contained to US equity futures
analysis_details:
• It is still unclear if Vice Premier Liu He will be part of the delegation
  • This comes after US President Trump stated over the weekend that the US will raise the 10% tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% beginning on Friday and suggested that USD 325bln of additional goods from China which remain untaxed, will be shortly at a rate of 25%, while he suggested the trade agreement with China is proceeding too slowly and firmly rejects efforts to renegotiate.
  • Earlier reports also stated that China is said to be mulling cancelling trade discussions this week following US President Trump's tariff threats. It was also reported that some working level Chinese officials have postponed their flights to the US and may fly as late as May 8th which is the date of the negotiations and that Chinese Vice Premier Liu He is very unlikely to go to the US this week, However, reports later suggested that Vice Premier Liu could delay his trip by 3 days and shorten it to only 1 day for trade talks. 
  • Subsequently, Chinese Foreign Ministry state that they hope the US can meet China halfway on trade talks the delegation is making preparations to go the US, and Ministry refrained to answer if Vice Premier He will partake in the delegation.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar bounces from post-NFP lows as Trump raises US-China tariff stakes
content:
DXY

The Greenback has regained some composure after Friday’s fall from grace on benign AHE vs healthy payroll gains, with the index just off best levels between 97.708-484 trading parameters and only the safer-haven Yen outperforming in G10 land. The catalyst has been renewed strains on the US-China trade front after President Trump scotched recent reports suggesting that a deal may be in the offing by repeating threats to increase tariffs on Usd200 bn Chinese imports to 25% from 10% as soon as this Friday and warning that a further Usd325 bn could follow.

JPY 

As noted above, Usd/Jpy has bucked the broader trend and remains off recent highs within a 110.30-97 range as broad aversion saw stocks and other risk assets shunned. However, the headline pair has rebounded ahead of a cluster of technical supports between 110.31-34, including 2 Fibs and a cloud base.

GBP/NZD/AUD/CAD/NOK/SEK

The Pound has now lost grip of the 1.3100 handle to test bids ahead of short term chart support around 1.3077 and after Cable failed to breach Fib resistance at 1.3116 as the Brexit limbo continues in UK holiday thinned conditions, while the non-US Dollars have all been hit by the risk-off start to the new week and concerns the global repercussions of US-China trade escalations, let alone a full blown tariff war. Aud/Usd has pared some losses to retest offers/supply ahead of 0.7000, but not quite enough to seriously test decent option expiry interest between the big figure and 0.70015 (1 bn). However, the Aussie still looks cautious in advance of Tuesday’s RBA policy meeting with rate cut odds relatively low, but perhaps not quite as ‘live’ as the looming RBNZ as Nzd/Usd hovers just above 0.6600 – for full previews of both see the Ransquawk Research Suite. The Loonie remains nearer the base of a 1.3493-29 range even though crude prices have regrouped, and elsewhere the Scandi Crowns are also underperforming in the anti-risk atmosphere, with Eur/Nok elevated between 9.7495-8050 and Eur/Sek from 10.6865 to 10.7400 in wake of a slowing Swedish services PMI.

EUR/CHF

The single currency and Swiss Franc have been a bit more resilient vs the Usd and in cross terms in the case of the latter. Eur/Usd has held up pretty well within a 1.1204-1.1161 raneg with the aid of more encouraging Eurozone macro news in the form of most services PMIs, retail sales and Sentix sentiment, while Usd/Chf has been capped just under 1.0200 and Eur/Chf saw a stop-run down to just a few pips off 1.1350 and the 200 DMA (1.1345) before revisiting 1.1400. Back to Eur/Usd, hefty option expiries may have influenced trade as 1.6 bn and 1.1 bn rolled off at the NY cut from 1.1150-60 and 1.1185-1.1200 respectively.

EM

Regional currencies have been on the back foot for the most part on broader safe-haven positioning, but Usd/Zar has extended gains ahead of the midweek SA elections to 14.5000+ vs some consolidation in Usd/Try and Usd/Chh from 6.0400 and 6.8200+ at one stage, with the Lira slipping through the psychological level following another call from the AKP to rerun the Istanbul local election and worrying remarks from the CBRT concerning inflation (PPI having a bigger impact on CPI).

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 6 May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

MACROECONOMIC

Luxury, Automotive, Agriculture and Technology sectors: US President Trump tweeted that for “10 months, China has been paying Tariffs to the USA of 25% on 50 Billion Dollars of High Tech, and 10% on 200 Billion Dollars of other goods. These payments are partially responsible for our great economic results. The 10% will go up to 25% on Friday. 325 Billion Dollars... of additional goods sent to us by China remain untaxed, but will be shortly, at a rate of 25%. The Tariffs paid to the USA have had little impact on product cost, mostly borne by China. The Trade Deal with China continues, but too slowly, as they attempt to renegotiate. No!”.

Furthermore, there were also initially reports that President Trump was told by aides that significant hurdles remain to reaching a trade agreement with China, but since these reports the Chinese Foreign Ministry has hit wires sounding more conciliatory, and stating their delegation is preparing to go to the US.

DOW

  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) – The iPhone maker are to be investigated by the EU on an antitrust basis after a formal complaint from Spotify (SPOT), as according to sources cited by the FT.
  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) – One of the aircraft makers 737 MAX planes skidded off a runway and into a river, after landing heavily in a thunderstorm in Florida. Elsewhere, a Russian Aeroflot passenger jet also caught fire on a runway in Moscow, killing 41 passengers. In other news, the aircraft maker reportedly did not share information about a problem with a cockpit safety alert for about a year before the issue drew attention with the October crash of a 737 Max jet in Indonesia, then only giving pilots and airlines partial and inconsistent explanations. Moreover, Boeing reportedly did not tell U.S. regulators for more than a year that it made an alarm alerting pilots to a mismatch of flight data optional on the 737 Max, rather than standard, as on earlier 737s models. In further damning reports, it is alleged that Boeing's board discussed how quickly and cheaply the 737 Max could be built but did not ask detailed questions about the airplane's safety.
  • Disney (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) – The media giant’s purchase of 21 regional sports networks from Sinclair Broadcast (SBGI) has been confirmed, at a value of USD 10.6bln. In other news, Ticket sales for "Avengers: Endgame" surpassed USD 2bln, with the movie now the 2nd highest grossing film of all time.
  • ExxonMobil (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) – The energy co are suing two Cuban companies and accuse them of illegally seizing properties in Cuba. Elsewhere, two shareholders reportedly said they would withhold their support for the re-election of all directors at the energy co's annual meeting, citing the U.S. oil major's alleged "inadequate response" to climate change
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) – The investment bank has estimated the upper end of their legal losses at USD 2.0bln in excess of aggregate reserves (vs. prev. USD 1.9bln).
  • Occidental Petroleum Corp (OXY) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) – The energy co has revised its offer to buy Anadarko (APC) to USD 59.00/shr cash and 0.2934 shares from USD 38.00/Shr and 0.6094 shares, which is around 23.3% premium to the offer from Chevron (CVX). Elsewhere, Occidental also reported revenue of USD 4.09bln vs. exp. 4.02bln, and EPS of USD 0.84 vs. exp. 0.73, average daily production of 719k BOE. Elsewhere, Occidental (OXY) and Total (TOT) have struck an agreement stating that total is to purchase Occidental's African assets for USD 8bln in the event that Occidental successfully acquires Anadarko. Moreover, Occidental have suspended their share buyback program.
  • Pfizer (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) – The pharma co. has announced approval from the FDA for Vyndaqel and Vyndamax for people with Cardiomyopathy and sate the price for Tafamidis will be SUD 225k in the US per year.

 

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – The technology giant’s Program Lead for Google Automotive Services McIntyre has been named as a director at Lithia Motors (LAD). Elsewhere, Barron's Kim says the co. is facing a sudden growth slowdown in its advertising business.
  • Biogen (BIIB) (Health Care/Biotechnology) – The biotech firm says that data from the SHIEN study for SPINRAZA has affirmed its longer-term safety.
  • Facebook (FB)/Twitter (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – Both companies were criticised by the US President on his Twitter page after banning multiple conservative-leaning accounts recently.
  • Kraft Heinz (KHC) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) – The consumer staples food maker are to restate their financial reports for 2016 & 2017 as the company have concluded that statements on cost recognition within these reports cannot be relied upon; as such costs of sale are to change. This investigation and review process also requires adjustments of USD 208mln. Additionally, a probe in the company identified multiple employees in procurement were engaged in misconduct. Chief marketing officer, Eduardo Luz, will leave the company
  • Tesla (TSLA) - The USTR has rejected a bid from Tesla to have its China-manufactured Model-3 computer removed from the basket of goods that may be subject to President Trump's 25% tariff. Elsewhere, Warren Buffett has criticised Tesla’s (TSLA) plans to enter the insurance business, saying they will likely face challenges in a field in which Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A, BRK.B) has thrived. Separately, they co. reportedly emailed their employees and warned of “consequences” if they violate their confidentiality agreements, as according to sources cited by CNBC.

S&P 500

  • Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A, BRK.B) (Financials/Multi-Sector Holding) (USD) reports earnings of 21.66bln vs. prev. -1.14bln, EPS 8.81 vs. prev. -0.46, operating earnings 5.56bln vs. prev. 5.29bln. In a speech Buffett stated their excess cash my be invested in index funds as opposed to T Bills and cash by his successor. Says they would like to put more cash into the UK. Adds that a US-China trade war won’t affect their business. Is in favour of Apple’s (AAPL) buyback programme, Kraft Heinz’s (KHC) restatement will not have a material effect and although there is “something going on” they have his confidence, and has no control over the Occidental (OXY) bid for Anadarko (APC).
  • Boston Scientific (BSX) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) – The health care equipment maker has announced FDA approval of their Vici Venous Stent System for treatment of iliofemoral venous obstructive disease.
  • CBS (CBS) (Communication Services/Broadcasting) – The broadcaster has announced a new anchor teams for their Evening News and This Morning broadcasts.
  • Conagra (CAG) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) – The food maker has announced their divestment of their frozen pasta business Gelit.
  • Fastenal (FAST) (Industrials/Building Products) (USD) report April net sales +12.5% to 460.71mln.
  • Ford (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) – The automaker has announced a collaboration with Gravity Sketch Sketch, in an effort to reduce designer workload through the use of 3D VR technology.
  • IBM (IBM) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services) – The technology co. expects their Red Hat acquisition to close in H2 2019, state that the DoJ have concluded their review of their purchase without conditions.
  • Johnson Controls (JCI) (Industrials/Building Products) – The industrial co are to buy back up to USD 4bln in common stock in a modified Dutch auction, at a single per-share purchase price not greater than USD 40.00 and not less than USD 36.00.
  • Teleflex (TFX) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) - have presented new data on their UroLift system, stating the results were “consistent with results found in controlled clinical studies, reaffirming the safety and long-term benefits of the minimally invasive UroLift System treatment for BPH”
  • Tyson Foods (TSN) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) – The food maker has expanded their recall of chicken breast strips after some customers found metals within the products. The co. also reported EPS USD 1.20 (exp. 1.14), Revenue USD 10.4bln (exp. 10.29bln). Elsewhere, the DoJ have issued a subpoena requesting the discovery that was produced in the Maplevale farms case.

 

OTHER

  • Acadia (ACAD) - The pharma co has filed to sell 40.2M shares of common stock for holders.
  • ArcelorMittal (MT) – The co are to curb production at their steelmaking facilities in Poland and reduce production in Asturias, Spain.
  • ASML (ASML) – The semiconductor co have won court proceedings against XTAL to the amount of USD 845mln in punitive damages.
  • Bausch Health (BHC) (USD) report GAAP EPS -0.15 vs. prev. -7.36 adj. EBITDA 851mln vs. prev. 832mln, raise FY 19 revenue view to 8.35-8.55bln vs. prev. 8.30-8.50
  • EQT (EQT) – The co will no longer undergo legal proceedings vs the co-founder of Rice Energy after he dropped his legal claims.
  • Fiat (FCAU) – The automaker has been described as an 'all American' Co. which should stand as a warning for a potential merger with Peugeot. Separately, the Mayor of Detroit stated that agreement has been achieved on all the required elements for the Co’s new Jeep factory in Detroit
  • Ichan Enterprises (IEP) have disclosed a subpoena vs. Manitowoc Trading (MTW).
  • Kosmos Energy (KOS) – The energy co has started the process to sell down their interest the Mauritania-Senegal basin to about 10%.
  • Lyft (LYFT) and Uber (UBER) - Drivers working for the two ride hailing technology companies are planning a strike this week over pay and working conditions.
  • Mallinckrodt (MNK) – The co have announced prelim results for their phase 4 for INOmax gas where approx. 86% of the analysed groups showed a 25% or greater improvement in OI or SOI during the treatment period.
  • Marvell (MRVL) - The technology co are to acquire Aquantia (AQ) for $13.25 per share in cash.
  • Park Hotels & Resorts (PK) – The hotel and resort co have announced a USD 2.7bln purchase of Chesapeake Lodging (CHSP); PK see USD 24mln 2020 EBITDA upside from the Cheaspeake portfolio. Park Hotels and Resorts also reported revenue of USD 659mln vs. exp. 659.82, adj. FFO USD 0.67 vs. exp. 0.17, raise FY 19 adj. FFO view to USD 2.93-3.07 vs. prev. 2.91-3.05
  • TransCanada (TRP) shareholders have confirmed their name change to TC Energy Corp.
  • Uber (UBER) – Berkshire’s Buffett has stated that he will not invest in the Uber IPO.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 6th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -2.0%] have succumbed to the risk off tone as US President Trump has threatened to hike tariffs on China, with Asia afflicted overnight from this, US equity futures are likewise subdued.
  • Subsequently, China’s Foreign Ministry states that they hope the US can meet China halfway and are preparing to go to the US; although, they refrained to comment in Vice Premier Liu He will attend.
  • In FX, safe havens propser while the remaining G10 currencies broadly underperform the USD
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Praet, Fed’s Harker and BoC’s Poloz. UK markets closed

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac indices and US equity futures began the week with heavy losses as US-China trade tensions flared up after President Trump tweeted that the US will raise the 10% tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% and suggested they will soon extend 25% tariffs to an additional USD 325bln of Chinese goods which are currently untaxed. Furthermore, China’s potential cancellation of this week’s trade discussions in Washington added to the pressure for equity futures and in turn wiped out all of Friday’s gains from the Goldilocks jobs report. ASX 200 (-0.8%) was negative with the index led lower by underperformance in tech and with the top-weighted financials sector also pressured amid losses in ‘Big 4’ bank Westpac after it reported a 24% drop in H1 statutory profit. Elsewhere, all components in the Hang Seng (-3.5%) were negative and the Shanghai Comp. (-5.2%) slumped heavily due to the renewed tariff threats which reportedly could shed 1.5% off China’s GDP growth, while a PBoC liquidity injection and targeted RRR cut for small and medium-sized banks, as well as mixed Caixin Services and Composite PMI data did little to brighten the sentiment in China. As a reminder, Japan and South Korea remained shut for Children’s Day.

US President Trump stated over the weekend that the US will raise the 10% tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% beginning on Friday and suggested that USD 325bln of additional goods from China which remain untaxed, will be shortly at a rate of 25%, while he suggested the trade agreement with China is proceeding too slowly and firmly rejects efforts to renegotiate. Furthermore, there were also reports that President Trump was told by aides that significant hurdles remain to reaching a trade agreement with China and a source familiar with President Trump’s thoughts on tariffs said that China have been backing away from agreements the US negotiating team believed they had already made. (Newswires/Twitter/Axios) This follows comments from President Trump on Friday that the US is doing fine with China regarding talks and that progress towards a deal are going "pretty well", while he added that a deal may happen in a couple of weeks although US will be fine if it doesn't happen. (Newswires)

China is said to be mulling cancelling trade discussions this week following US President Trump's tariff threats. It was also reported that some working level Chinese officials have postponed their flights to the US and may fly as late as May 8th which is the date of the negotiations and that Chinese Vice Premier Liu He is very unlikely to go to the US this week, However, reports later suggested that Vice Premier Liu could delay his trip by 3 days and shorten it to only 1 day for trade talks. (WSJ/Global Times/Twitter/SCMP)

Subsequently, Chinese Foreign Ministry state that they hope the US can meet China halfway on trade talks the delegation is making preparations to go the US, and Ministry refrained to answer if Vice Premier He will partake in the delegation. Addeed that their Navy has instructed US ships to leave the South China Sea and refrain from such provocative acts. (Newswires)

PBoC is to set lower reserve requirements for small and medium sized banks effective May 15th which will release CNY 280bln of long-term funds. (Newswires)

PBoC injected a net CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7344 (Prev. 6.7286)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Apr) 54.5 vs. Exp. 54.2 (Prev. 54.4). (Newswires) Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Apr) 52.7     (Prev. 52.9)

 

US

Fed’s Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said inflation has consistently fallen below the Fed target and stated the economy is in a good state so now is the time to examine the Fed framework, while she added that an average inflation target would be a more attractive option. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May is said to be optimistic she is nearing a deal with the opposition Labour party on Brexit, while Foreign Minister Hunt commented that there is a glimmer of hope the government can reach a Brexit compromise with Labour. It was reported that PM May’s officials were drafting a new law ahead of a potential Brexit deal with the Labour party in an attempt to break the ongoing stalemate; the move would help ensure a customs unions arrangement and guarantee that there are no checks on goods flowing between the UK-EU border. However, there were later reports that suggested PM May was warned that more than 100 MPs would attempt to block a soft Brexit. (Newswires/BuzzFeed)

UK PM May reportedly held secret discussions concerning a 3-way referendum in which she carried out scenario planning with aides and ministers in the event they cannot prevent a parliamentary vote on a 2nd referendum. (Telegraph)

UK Shadow Chancellor McDonnell poured cold water on PM May’s plan for a temporary customs union in exchange for Labour support and likened the cross-party discussions as similar to entering a contract with a company going into administration. In related news, Shadow Health Secretary Ashworth also dismissed talk of an early compromise and suggested that PM May’s proposals would risk US health giants getting their hands on the NHS, while it was also reported that Labour MPs will not back the Brexit deal without a 2nd referendum. (The Guardian/Independent)

UK Chancellor Hammond is mulling a significant hike to the minimum wage to GBP 9.61 per hour from current GBP 8.21 per hour. (The Guardian)

Italian Deputy PM Di Maio states that he does not see any risk of the government collapsing due to the Graft case which involves a League undersecretary, adds that the government is not at risk unless the League Party opens a government crisis during the next cabinet meeting. (Newswires)

EU Markit Comp Final PMI (Apr) 51.5 vs. Exp. 51.3 (Prev. 51.3)

- EU Markit Services Final PMI (Apr) 52.8 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.5)

- German Markit Services PMI (Apr) 55.7 vs. Exp. 55.6 (Prev. 55.6)

- German Markit Comp Final PMI (Apr) 52.2 vs. Exp. 52.1 (Prev. 52.1)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

 

US President Trump tweeted that North Korea leader Kim knows that “I am with him & does not want to break his promise to me”, while he added a deal will happen. In related news, there were reports over the weekend that North Korea test fired several short-range missiles which travelled 70km-200km eastwards. (Newswires/Twitter)

 

US National Security Adviser Bolton said US is deploying a carrier strike group and bomber task force to US Central Command region to send a clear message to Iran that any attack on US interests or allies will be met with unrelenting force. (Newswires)

US renewed sanction waivers allowing UK, Russia, China and France to continue non-proliferation work with Iran, although it could place sanctions if Iran exchanges enriched uranium for natural uranium and will permit a continuation of projects that restrict Iran's ability to restart its defunct nuclear weapons program. (Newswires)

 

Eastern Libya forces led by Khalifa Haftar conducted airstrikes on targets in Tripoli and said they have destroyed the Government of National Accord's operation headquarters. (Newswires)

 

 

EQUITIES

Major European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -2.0%] have begun the week with heavy losses in-line with their Asian counterparts and US equity futures as markets move back into risk-off mode following US President Trump tweeting that the US will raise tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods from 10% to 25% and indicated that they will consider extending the scope of tariffs to include an additional USD 325bln of goods which are currently not taxed. However, subsequent comments from China’s Foreign Ministry, that they hope the US can meet China halfway on trade talks and that the delegation are preparing to go to the US, did generate a glimmer of positivity across markets. Although, it is still unclear if Vice Premier Liu He will feature in this delegation. Losses across European indices are broad based with no standout under/out performer, and a similar scene is present across sectors. Although, luxury names such as Christian Dior (-3.7%) and Kering (-3.0%) are heavily weighed on by the increased US-China trade tensions. Similarly, auto names are lower due to their supply chains being particularly vulnerable to trade tensions, Volkswagen (-3.5%) have been hit the hardest, with the Co’s CEO previously stating that import tariffs from the US on the EU could cost the Co. billions of euros each year. Other notable movers this morning include ThyssenKrupp (-4.2%) amidst reports that EU anti-trust regulators are likely to block the Co’s proposed merger with Tata Steel due to concerns over potential price increases and the impact on competition; the proposed merger would create Europe’s second largest steel producer and follows comments from Tata Steel’s European Works Council that they do not believe the merger is in the best interest of the Co’s workers. At the other end of the Stoxx 600, and today’s only notable mover in positive territory are Telenor (+4.0%) following reports that the Co. and Axiata have initiated discussions to merge their Asian operations with the Co. likely to own 56.5% of the merger.

Boeing (BA) has stated that it knew of a problem with its 737 Max jets around a year prior to the aircraft being involved in an accident,  but that they did not take any action on this  Stating that they inadvertently made an alarm feature optional, instead of making it a standard feature; though continue to insist that that should not impact flight safety. Elsewhere, 737 plane skidded off a runway and into a river, after landing heavily in a thunderstorm in Florida. (Newswires)

FX

JPY/CHF - While the Usd holds above Friday’s post-NFP lows and the DXY pivots around 97.500, safe-haven positioning in wake of latest US-Chinese trade developments and a diplomatic spat between the 2 nations over naval vessels in the South China Sea has heightened demand for the Yen and Franc. Following Trump tweets threatening to imposes higher tariffs on Usd200 bn worth of Chinese goods this Friday with a further Usd325 bn possibly subject to increased levies, Usd/Jpy reversed through 111.00 and all the way down to circa 110.30, while stops are said to have been tripped in Eur/Chf on a break of 1.1370 pushing the cross towards 1.1350 and the 200 DMA (1.1345). However, some respite has tempered aversion as China’s Foreign Affairs Ministry says a delegation is still preparing to head to Washington this week and subsequently seen rebounds to around 110.70 and 1.1375 respectively.

GBP/AUD/CAD/NZD/NOK/SEK - The main G10 underperformers and casualties of the broad risk off start to the new week, as Cable probes support ahead of 1.3100 amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty and the UK public holiday, while the Aussie, Loonie and Kiwi are all trying to stabilise following declines to 0.6963, 1.3493 and 0.6601. Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are also maintaining a defensive stance in the run up to RBA and RBNZ policy meetings that are both expected to be ‘live’ in terms of easing prospects, while the deterioration in US-China relations has also undermined oil to the detriment of the Cad and Nok (latter down near 9.8000 vs the Eur). Back down under, hefty option expiry interest may provide support and resistance in Aud/Usd given 1.1 bn at the 0.6950 strike and 1 bn at 0.7000-15. Elsewhere, Eur/Sek is elevated around 10.7200 on the back of another soft Swedish PMI as the services headline dips, albeit still comfortably above the 50.0 threshold unlike manufacturing.

EUR - Conversely, an upward revision to the final pan Eurozone services PMI despite mixed national surveys, slightly firmer than expected retail sales data and an encouraging Sentix Index have all helped the single currency contain losses within a 1.1200-1.1160 range vs the Dollar. Note also, decent option expiry interest could be keeping the headline pair rangebound as 1.6 bn runs off between 1.1150-60 vs 1.1 bn from 1.1185-1.1200.

EM - Widespread losses vs the Greenback amidst the aforementioned generally sour sentiment, as Usd/Cnh rallies through 6.8000 at one stage vs the PBoC’s official 6.3744 Usd/Cny fix, while Usd/Zar tests offers ahead of 14.5000 in advance of Wednesday’s SA elections and Usd/Try peers over 6.0000 on the ongoing and well documented Turkish, plus CBRT concerns about (higher) PPI cost pressures exerting and increasingly stronger influence on CPI.

FIXED INCOME

The risk premium in Bunds and US Treasuries continues to fade even though stocks and Italian bonds remain under pressure on the flare up in US-China trade wars and political wrangling in Rome. The 10 year German debt future is sitting just above a 165.37 low and almost ½ point off best levels, while US equivalents have retreated from their overnight session, albeit still holding a firmer bid awaiting the return of Wall Street with futures pointing to very heavy losses. Back to Italy, BTPS look vulnerable through early May lows, but have retained 130.00+ status by a whisker in wake of a sub-50 composite PMI.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-1.0%) and WTI (-1.3%) have also succumbed to the general risk tone, although are currently trading within a relatively thin band with prices having recovered from overnight lows which were just a shade below USD 69/bbl and just above the USD 60/bbl levels respectively. Aside from the all-encompassing US-China story news flow for the complex has been somewhat thin, notably Saudi Aramco raised their OSP for all crude grades to all regions (ex-US) for June, with Arab Light’s price falling by USD 0.10/bbl for the US.

Gold (+0.3%), along with other safe havens, has benefitted from the increased US-China tension and the resulting risk off sentiment, with the yellow metal now trading towards the middle of a USD 7/oz range which did see it reach USD 1287/oz. Copper, has suffered as the metals largest buyer China returned to market, after a 3-day Labour Day holiday last week, with China playing catchup and sentiment being impacted by updates regarding the potential increase or imposition of tariffs on China. Iron ore port holdings in China fell 1.8% to 133.6mln tons which is the lowest since October 2017. (Newswires)

subject: Oil flows through the Northern and Southern routes of the Druzhba pipeline to Europe has reportedly not resumed, whilst the Ust-Luga port (Russian Baltic sea port) continues to load contaminated oil, according to sources
analysis_details: • Last week, reports noted that the Druzhba pipleine will take up to 6 months to come back to full operations, as according to Belta

subject: European equity movers this morning: Telenor (TEL NO) +1.8%; ArcelorMittal (MT NA) -4.2%; ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) -3.3%; Kering (KER FP) -3.0%; LVMH (MC FP) -2.6%; Airbus (AIR FP) -2.6%; Total (FP FP) -1.5%; Altice (ATC NA) -1.3%
Bunds: off overnight peaks, but retaining firm safe-haven bid
content: The 10 year German benchmark has drifted back from best levels after ¼ point initial mark up and extended rally to 165.86 vs last Friday’s 165.26 close amidst ramped up risk aversion on the back of US President Trump’s weekend warning about new and higher tariffs on Chinese goods. His latest tweets have shocked financial markets that were almost assuming a trade deal would be agreed in the near future following a string of positive reports about the state of negotiations, including several from the White House suggesting that talks are in the final stages. Bunds are currently 37 ticks ahead and eyeing the EU stock opens for further direction and a statement from China’s Foreign Affairs Office also due at 8.00BST to see whether a trip planned this week will still go ahead. Also coming up, Eurozone services PMIs, Sentix and a couple of ECB speakers.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – India’s Top Court reportedly allows protection to the Co. against a INR 5bln penalty, court directs that no coercive action is to be taken against the Co; according to CNBC. (Newswires)

Scout 24 (G24 GY) – Hellman & Friedman state that Pulver Bidco are offering the Co’s shareholders the opportunity to tender their shared for a consideration of EUR 46.00 per share, Pulver Bidco have stated that if the offer fails they will not instigate a additional offer for the Co. for at least 12 months. (Newswires)

Stabilus (STM GY) - Co. have cut their guidance, for FY19 assume sales at the prior years level and confirm an adj. EBIT margin of approximately 15%. (Newswires)

Altice (ATC NA) – Co. states that it has successfully refinanced its debt, as part of a deal which would result in cash savings. (Newswires)

ArcelorMittal (MT NA) - Co. are to temporarily reduce annualised European primary steel-making production by 3mln tonnes, due to; weaker demand, rising imports, insufficient EU trade protections, high energy costs and increasing carbon costs. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

6th May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac indices and US equity futures began the week with heavy losses as US-China trade tensions flared up after President Trump tweeted that the US will raise the 10% tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% and suggested they will soon extend 25% tariffs to an additional USD 325bln of Chinese goods which are currently untaxed. Furthermore, China’s potential cancellation of this week’s trade discussions in Washington added to the pressure for equity futures and in turn wiped out all of Friday’s gains from the Goldilocks jobs report. ASX 200 (-0.8%) was negative with the index led lower by underperformance in tech and with the top-weighted financials sector also pressured amid losses in ‘Big 4’ bank Westpac after it reported a 24% drop in H1 statutory profit. Elsewhere, all components in the Hang Seng (-3.5%) were negative and the Shanghai Comp. (-5.2%) slumped heavily due to the renewed tariff threats which reportedly could shed 1.5% of China’s GDP growth, while a PBoC liquidity injection and targeted RRR cut for small and medium-sized banks, as well as mixed Caixin Services and Composite PMI data did little to brighten the sentiment in China. As a reminder, Japan and South Korea remained shut for Children’s Day.

FTSE

Gambling Names – Co’s will be required to verify customers are 18 before funds are placed into an account, online operators will additionally have to verify customers names and addresses in rules from the Gambling Commission which come into effect on Tuesday. (FT)

BT (BT/A LN) – Co’s CEO Jansen reportedly favours reducing shareholder pay-outs as Openreach increases the roll out of faster and more reliable fibre networks, however, the Co’s Chairman Plessis reportedly prefers to maintain the Co’s dividend and his own standing; as he has previously insisted that new leadership would not result in another change to pay-outs. Separately, Co’s CEO is to begin his tenure by instigating a bolder approach to fibre investment, expected to be unveiled on Thursday when the Co. are due to report their earnings. (Telegraph/FT)

Severn Trent (SNT LN) – UK Labour leader Corbyn stated that a future Labour government would offer shareholders in UK water Utilities GBP 20bln in a nationalisation programme, which compares with the current market value of approximately GBP 44bln. (Twitter/Times/Newswires)

Whitbread (WTB LN) – Shareholder Elliott has called for the Co. to offload parts of its GBP 5.8bln property portfolio. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Co.’s rights offering is reportedly to be priced at GBP 4-4.50/shr. (Newswires)

G4S (GFS LN) – Garda World Security has announced that they do not intend to make an offer for the Co. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – EU Anti-trust regulators are reportedly likely to block the Co’s merger with Tata Steel due to concerns that it would damage competition and lead to price increases. EU Competition Commissioner is reportedly to rule against the venture unless there are changes to their plans. Although, the Co. state that it still sees scope for agreement with the antitrust regulators. (Telegraph/FT/Newswires)

Siemens (SIE GY) – Co. are reportedly considering the sale of its gas & power unit. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Reports indicate that voting advisor Ivox is concerned about the ratification of the management and supervisory boards business conduct, recommending to shareholders that at the very least this should be ‘critically questioned at least’; according to Boersen Zeitung. Additionally, Shareholders have been recommended by Glass Lewis to vote against ratification of management and supervisory boards at the AGM. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Carl Zeiss (AFX GY) – H2 EBIT EUR 110.4mln vs. Prev. EUR 88.2mln. Co. expects to achieve sales of EUR 1.350-1.420bln for FY19, and an EBIT margin of 15-17.5%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – A Boeing (BA) 737 plane skidded off of a runway and into a river, after landing heavily in a thunderstorm. Separately, Co. are looking at suing Germany over the arms export ban, according to reports (BBC/Newswires)

Total (FP FP) – Co. has struck an agreement with Occidental to purchase African assets for USD 8bln in the event that Occidental successfully acquires Anadarko. (Newswires)

Carrefour (CA FP) – A union spokesperson has stated that the Co. could lay off up to 3000 people. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Euronext (ENX FP) – The two largest shareholders of Oslo Børs are reportedly looking to block Euronext’s attempted takeover of the Co. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM)/ Peugeot (UG FP) - Fiat has been described as an 'all American' Co. which should stand as a warning for a potential merger with Peugeot. Separately, the Mayor of Detroit stated that agreement has been achieved on all the required elements for the Co’s new Jeep factory in Detroit.(WSJ/Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Banks advising the Co. have reportedly recommended that it purchase Open Fiber in exchange for Co. shares and then instigate a merger of their networks. Elliot, Vivendi and CDP may back this move but Enel’s position in unknown; according to La Repubblica. (Newswires)

Mediobanca (MB IM) – 2% of the Co’s share capital is to be given to the partners of Messier Maris & Associes; according to Il Sole 24 Ore. (Newswires)

ASML (ASML NA) – US Court has ruled in favour of the Co. against Xtal, with the court awarding USD 845mln along with an injunction. The judgement will be uncollectable as Xtal is in bankruptcy as such the Co. are likely to acquire most/all of Xtal’s IP through the bankruptcy process. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 6th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asia-Pac indices and US equity futures began the week with heavy losses as President Trump heightens tensions in the US-China trade war
  • Subsequently, China is reportedly mulling cancelling trade discussions this week following US President Trump's tariff threats
  • UK PM May remains optimistic that she is nearing a deal with the opposition Labour party on Brexit; MPs in her party and across the aisle are less upbeat about the prospects for a deal
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Services PMIs, ECB’s Lautenschlaeger, Praet, Fed’s Evans, Harker and BoC’s Poloz. UK markets closed

 

6th May 2019 

·        Asia-Pac indices and US equity futures began the week with heavy losses as President Trump heightens tensions in the US-China trade war

·        Subsequently, China is reportedly mulling cancelling trade discussions this week following US President Trump's tariff threats

·        UK PM May remains optimistic that she is nearing a deal with the opposition Labour party on Brexit; MPs in her party and across the aisle are less upbeat about the prospects for a deal

·        Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Services PMIs, ECB’s Lautenschlaeger, Praet, Fed’s Evans, Harker and BoC’s Poloz. UK markets closed

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac indices and US equity futures began the week with heavy losses as US-China trade tensions flared up after President Trump tweeted that the US will raise the 10% tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% and suggested they will soon extend 25% tariffs to an additional USD 325bln of Chinese goods which are currently untaxed. Furthermore, China’s potential cancellation of this week’s trade discussions in Washington added to the pressure for equity futures and in turn wiped out all of Friday’s gains from the Goldilocks jobs report. ASX 200 (-0.8%) was negative with the index led lower by underperformance in tech and with the top-weighted financials sector also pressured amid losses in ‘Big 4’ bank Westpac after it reported a 24% drop in H1 statutory profit. Elsewhere, all components in the Hang Seng (-3.5%) were negative and the Shanghai Comp. (-5.2%) slumped heavily due to the renewed tariff threats which reportedly could shed 1.5% of China’s GDP growth, while a PBoC liquidity injection and targeted RRR cut for small and medium-sized banks, as well as mixed Caixin Services and Composite PMI data did little to brighten the sentiment in China. As a reminder, Japan and South Korea remained shut for Children’s Day.

US President Trump stated over the weekend that the US will raise the 10% tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% beginning on Friday and suggested that USD 325bln of additional goods from China which remain untaxed, will be shortly at a rate of 25%, while he suggested the trade agreement with China is proceeding too slowly and firmly rejects efforts to renegotiate. Furthermore, there were also reports that President Trump was told by aides that significant hurdles remain to reaching a trade agreement with China and a source familiar with President Trump’s thoughts on tariffs said that China have been backing away from agreements the US negotiating team believed they had already made. (Newswires/Twitter/Axios) This follows comments from President Trump on Friday that the US is doing fine with China regarding talks and that progress towards a deal are going "pretty well", while he added that a deal may happen in a couple of weeks although US will be fine if it doesn't happen. (Newswires)

China is said to be mulling cancelling trade discussions this week following US President Trump's tariff threats. It was also reported that some working level Chinese officials have postponed their flights to the US and may fly as late as May 8th which is the date of the negotiations and that Chinese Vice Premier Liu He is very unlikely to go to the US this week, However, reports later suggested that Vice Premier Liu could delay his trip by 3 days and shorten it to only 1 day for trade talks. (WSJ/Global Times/Twitter/SCMP)

PBoC is to set lower reserve requirements for small and medium sized banks effective May 15th which will release CNY 280bln of long-term funds. (Newswires)

PBoC injected a net CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7344 (Prev. 6.7286)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Apr) 54.5 vs. Exp. 54.2 (Prev. 54.4). (Newswires) Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Apr) 52.7     (Prev. 52.9)

UK/EU

UK PM May is said to be optimistic she is nearing a deal with the opposition Labour party on Brexit, while Foreign Minister Hunt commented that there is a glimmer of hope the government can reach a Brexit compromise with Labour. It was reported that PM May’s officials were drafting a new law ahead of a potential Brexit deal with the Labour party in an attempt to break the ongoing stalemate; the move would help ensure a customs unions arrangement and guarantee that there are no checks on goods flowing between the UK-EU border. However, there were later reports that suggested PM May was warned that more than 100 MPs would attempt to block a soft Brexit. (Newswires/BuzzFeed)

UK PM May reportedly held secret discussions concerning a 3-way referendum in which she carried out scenario planning with aides and ministers in the event they cannot prevent a parliamentary vote on a 2nd referendum. (Telegraph)

UK Shadow Chancellor McDonnell poured cold water on PM May’s plan for a temporary customs union in exchange for Labour support and likened the cross-party discussions as similar to entering a contract with a company going into administration. In related news, Shadow Health Secretary Ashworth also dismissed talk of an early compromise and suggested that PM May’s proposals would risk US health giants getting their hands on the NHS, while it was also reported that Labour MPs will not back the Brexit deal without a 2nd referendum. (The Guardian/Independent)

UK Chancellor Hammond is mulling a significant hike to the minimum wage to GBP 9.61 per hour from current GBP 8.21 per hour. (The Guardian)

Portuguese PM Costa said the motion passed on Thursday is financially unsustainable and that they always balanced budget consolidation with other measures, while he warned that the government would be forced to resign if Parliament gives final approval to the budget. (Newswires)

 

FX

 

In FX markets, the DXY was flat around 97.50 following its retreat from the 98.00 level in the aftermath of Friday’s US jobs numbers. EUR/USD gapped below the 1.1200 handle and GBP/USD was weaker as senior figures in the opposition Labour party casted doubts on a cross-party deal to break the Brexit deadlock, while reports also noted that Labour MPs will not back the Brexit deal without a 2nd referendum. The risk averse tone from Trump’s tariff offensive spurred safe-haven flows with the downside in USD/JPY and JPY-crosses exacerbated by the absence of participants in Japan, while CNH weakened by 5 points in the fallout of the return of the ‘Tariff Man’. Elsewhere, antipodeans were also pressured with AUD/USD below 0.7000 and NZD/USD briefly tested the 0.6600 level to the downside due to their high-beta statuses and China exposure, as well as the potential ramifications trade uncertainty could gave at the upcoming ‘live’ rate decisions from both sides of the Tasman this week.

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mostly weaker amid the increased US-China trade tensions which weighed heavily on WTI crude futures as they fell towards the USD 60.00/bbl level where it eventually found some mild support to help recoup some of the intraday losses of more than 3.0%. Elsewhere, gold was underpinned by the risk averse tone and extended on Friday gains which were spurred by a weaker greenback after soft wage growth data, while copper was pressured amid heavy losses in it largest buyer China and after Shanghai metal prices fell around 3% shortly after the open.

Baker Hughes (May 3): oil rigs +2 at 807, gas rigs -3 at 183, total rigs at 990. (Newswires) Iron ore port holdings in China fell 1.8% to 133.6mln tons which is the lowest since October 2017. (Newswires) 

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump tweeted that North Korea leader Kim knows that “I am with him & does not want to break his promise to me”, while he added a deal will happen. In related news, there were reports over the weekend that North Korea test fired several short-range missiles which travelled 70km-200km eastwards. (Newswires/Twitter)

US National Security Adviser Bolton said US is deploying a carrier strike group and bomber task force to US Central Command region to send a clear message to Iran that any attack on US interests or allies will be met with unrelenting force. (Newswires)

US renewed sanction waivers allowing UK, Russia, China and France to continue non-proliferation work with Iran, although it could place sanctions if Iran exchanges enriched uranium for natural uranium and will permit a continuation of projects that restrict Iran's ability to restart its defunct nuclear weapons program. (Newswires)

Eastern Libya forces led by Khalifa Haftar conducted airstrikes on targets in Tripoli and said they have destroyed the Government of National Accord's operation headquarters. (Newswires) 

US

UST futures closed out the week lower on the day after a blow-out headline figure for NFPs, which saw some volatile action upon the release as average hourly earnings missed on their 0.3% and 3.3% forecast (0.2% and 3.2% respectively). Thus, 10yr yields didn’t sustain their initial bid and failed to break its 50DMA, with the bounce linked a block of 6k TYM9 supposedly lifted by a hedge fund. Thereafter, 7k USM9s were bought ahead of the ISM results, with the fixed income complex gaining speed afters some disappointing results. Fed speakers then took centre stage, with a largely neutral tone exhibited that fell in-line with FOMC guidance, ex-Evans, which kept T-notes within ranges heading to the close. US T-note futures (m9) settled 13 ticks higher at 61.94.

Fed's Bullard (Voter, Dove) said he is open to rate cut if inflation is still low after the summer, while he added that Fed policy is a little tight and that low inflation as well as inflation expectations are concerning. (Newswires)

Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said inflation is muted but sees inflation expectations as stable, while he described the US economy as being at, or close to, the Fed's objectives on both inflation and unemployment. Furthermore, Clarida suggested the economy is in a "very good place" and the Fed can afford to monitor incoming data. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Voter, Neutral) said the Fed is in the neighbourhood of neutral rates and that he views economic growth at roughly 2.25% this year, while he is worried about weak growth in the Eurozone and its effect on the US. (Newswires)

Fed’s Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said inflation has consistently fallen below the Fed target and stated the economy is in a good state so now is the time to examine the Fed framework, while she added that an average inflation target would be a more attractive option. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (Non-voter, Hawk) said she does not believe in a rate cut yet. (Newswires)

Thomas A. Roe Institute for Economic Policy Studies Director Paul Winfree is being considered for the Federal Reserve, according to sources. (WSJ)
